title: Canadian C-Spine Rule
description: The Canadian C-Spine Rule is a clinical decision tool that helps determine whether cervical spine imaging can be safely avoided in alert and stable trauma patients. It uses high-risk factors, low-risk factors, and range of motion assessment to rule out clinically significant cervical spine injury (CSI) with 100% sensitivity.

parameters.name: age_65_or_over
parameters.description: Is the patient aged 65 years or older?

parameters.name: dangerous_mechanism
parameters.description: Was there a dangerous mechanism of injury? (fall from >3 feet/5 steps, axial load to head e.g. diving, high-speed MVC >100km/hr, rollover MVC, ejection from vehicle, motorized recreational vehicle accident, bicycle collision)

parameters.name: paresthesias_in_extremities
parameters.description: Are there paresthesias (numbness/tingling) in the extremities?

parameters.name: simple_rear_end_mvc
parameters.description: Was it a simple rear-end motor vehicle collision? (excludes: pushed into traffic, hit by bus/large truck, rollover, hit by high-speed vehicle)

parameters.name: sitting_position_in_ed
parameters.description: Is the patient sitting upright in the Emergency Department?

parameters.name: ambulatory_at_any_time
parameters.description: Has the patient been ambulatory (able to walk) at any time since the injury?

parameters.name: delayed_onset_neck_pain
parameters.description: Was there delayed onset of neck pain (not immediate)?

parameters.name: absence_midline_tenderness
parameters.description: Is there absence of midline cervical spine tenderness?

parameters.name: able_to_rotate_neck
parameters.description: Is the patient able to actively rotate neck 45 degrees left AND right? (Only assess if no high-risk factors AND at least one low-risk factor present)

outcomes.interpretation: The patient has high-risk factors that mandate radiography (age ≥65 years, dangerous mechanism, or paresthesias in extremities). Proceed with cervical spine imaging as clinically indicated.
The patient has low-risk factors allowing safe assessment of range of motion AND can actively rotate neck 45° left and right. The cervical spine can be cleared clinically without imaging.
Although the patient has low-risk factors, they are unable to actively rotate their neck 45° left and right. Cervical spine imaging is required.

outcomes.result: Imaging Required - No Low Risk Factors
outcomes.interpretation: The patient has no high-risk factors but also lacks any low-risk factors that would allow safe assessment of range of motion. Cervical spine imaging is required.

references: Stiell IG, Wells GA, Vandemheen KL, Clement CM, Lesiuk H, De Maio VJ, et al. The Canadian C-spine rule for radiography in alert and stable trauma patients. JAMA. 2001 Oct 17;286(15):1841-8. doi: 10.1001/jama.286.15.1841.

Stiell IG, Clement CM, McKnight RD, Brison R, Schull MJ, Rowe BH, et al. The Canadian C-spine rule versus the NEXUS low-risk criteria in patients with trauma. N Engl J Med. 2003 Dec 25;349(26):2510-8. doi: 10.1056/NEJMoa031375.

Stiell IG, Clement CM, Grimshaw J, Brison RJ, Rowe BH, Schull MJ, et al. Implementation of the Canadian C-Spine Rule: prospective 12 centre cluster randomised trial. BMJ. 2009 Oct 29;339:b4146. doi: 10.1136/bmj.b4146.
formula: Decision algorithm: 1) If any high-risk factor present → Imaging required; 2) If no high-risk factors AND at least one low-risk factor → Assess range of motion; 3) If able to rotate neck 45° left and right → No imaging; 4) If unable to rotate or no low-risk factors → Imaging required
notes: Only applicable to alert (GCS 15) and stable trauma patients
Age requirement: ≥16 years (some sources specify 16-64 years)
Exclusions: penetrating trauma, known vertebral disease, pregnancy
100% sensitivity for clinically significant cervical spine injuries in validation studies
Simple rear-end MVC excludes: pushed into traffic, hit by bus/large truck, rollover, hit by high-speed vehicle
